questions.question: The children were ....................... going to the movies, but the rain played spoilsport.
questions.description: When you are set on doing something, you believe that it will happen.

questions.question: The girl didn't take even five minutes to ......................... the train set.
questions.description: To set up something is to put together.

questions.question: What sets him ................... from his colleagues is his commitment to his work.
questions.description: Set apart = make something or someone distinct from others.

questions.question: She set ................. the novel and started doing her homework.
questions.description: To set something aside is to put it to the side because you don't want to use it at the moment.

questions.question: She has faced many ................... in life.
questions.description: Setback is written as one word. A setback is an unfavorable situation that hinders your progress.

questions.question: He set the stereo ................... on the table.
questions.description: To set something down is to put it down.

questions.question: Winter has set ..................
questions.description: When a season sets in, it begins to happen.

questions.question: Three months after quitting the job, remorse set ...............
questions.description: When feelings set in, they begin to be felt.

questions.question: We set .................... on our voyage in the morning.
questions.description: To set off is to begin a journey.

questions.question: The decision to build a dam in the ecologically sensitive region set ................... a wave of protests.
questions.description: To set off an event is to trigger it.

questions.question: The merchant set .................... on his journey in the morning.
questions.description: To set out on a journey is to start it. Set off also means the same.

questions.question: They set .................... the tent in a couple of minutes.
